p: Kidney dysfunction, including both acute and chronic renal failure, is a known complication of HIV infection. The aetiology of HIV-associated acute kidney disease is thought to involve the virus itself, co-morbid diseases or infections and anti-retroviral therapy [ 7]. Thus, acute renal failure has been linked to the use of indinavir and tenofovir, and can progress to chronic kidney disease if not treated [ 8, 9]. Indinavir is associated with nephrolithiasis, papillary necrosis, and dysuria [ 8, 10] while tenofovir has been implicated in tubular toxicity and Fanconi syndrome [ 11]. With regard to chronic kidney disease (CKD), the prevalence of this disorder has been reported to be between 6.0–45% in HIV infected, ART-naïve subjects in sub-Saharan Africa [ 12]. The development of CKD in those infected with HIV is thought to be mediated by viral proteins, host genetic variants, and environmental factors [ 7].
